title: Corp Tax Avoiders - Net Benefit To Economy?
text: Scuffers said: fblm said: Personally I find allowing multinationals to avoid tax that 'local' SME's can't unjustifiable and would argue the answer is to scrap CT or lower it to a point avoidance is more costly than paying. problem with that is just how low would you have to set it to before companies start to pay it.bear in mind it's only the big multi-nationals that can afford the tax consultants to do this stuff, so the smaller companies are already facing unfair competition.I agree with the principle of not having high CT rates, but reducing them to low single digit would be pointless. Isn't the issue with that approach that it's a race to the bottom.Somewhere like (say) Luxembourg has about the same population as Croydon and would probably be very happy to receive 1% of all European companies profits if they set a 1% corp tax rate that everyone decided to use. Each citizen would probably be as rich as the average Saudi national.In fact, Luxembourg benefited for years by levying a 15% VAT rate which meant that it was the cheapest in europe and they made shedloads of free money before the EU mandated that companies have to charge the rate at the point of sale.inho, if the EU is good for anything then it must close these loopholes and ensure that money is taxed fairly before it leaves europe,Even within Europe there are loopholes. One of the low countries (I think) doesn't tax income from intellectual property so many multinationals charge a massive fee for use of intellectual property to their subsidiaries; guess where it's paid.There should be a tax law that says something like .. "if it looks hinky then it is hinky"ETA: looks like Luxembourg are already onto the intellectual property loophole: http://merlin.obs.coe.int/iris/2008/3/article23.en...
